title.narrative: Conservation of the Early 19th-Century Fourah Bay College Building in Freetown

description.narrative: The first Western-style university in West Africa, Fourah Bay College was the preferred educational institution of freed African American, West Indian, and liberated African slaves and their descendants. This project involves documentation, stabilization, and the development of a restoration plan for the building.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Ruins of 18th-Century and Other Structures on Bunce Island Associated with the Transatlantic Slave Trade

description.narrative: As a major slave fort, Bunce Island was part of an economic and demographic dynamic that transformed Africa, the United States, the Caribbean, and Europe between the late 17th and early 19th centuries. This project, which involves conservation of the fort ruins and measures to reduce the risk of coastal erosion, directly supports the U.S. embassys efforts to support economic development and recovery in the aftermath of the 2014 Ebola virus outbreak.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Temporary Shelter for Survivors of Human Trafficking in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: These funds will provide an extension to a current project that provides holistic recovery and reintegration services to female victims of trafficking. WHI will continue to work with village parent groups to prevent trafficking from rural areas to the cities, and to facilitate the reintegration of survivors. WHI will also continue its collaborative work with community anti-trafficking groups, local law enforcement personnel and victim service providers to develop a coordinated response to TIP through service provision and raising TIP awareness.
